candidate_text: One can just imagine the panic button being pressed behind closed doors, as frantic board members confer with their lawyers and PR experts about how best to contain the damage (read: lie, least untruthfully) after another day, another outbreak.
The burritos still good (if pricey), but the shtick is starting to grate.
This popular burrito joint has been slammed with food safety concerns, with reports of customers getting sick in multiple states, and some locations shut down after norovirus outbreaks.

One moment, you think your beloved burrito is safe and the next thing you know... pic.twitter.com/5XrDjJx4cB â€” Kevin (@kclements20) October 28, 2019 But let's not overlook the most important aspect of this situation: there are reports that customers have been experiencing " gastrointestinal issues" after eating at Chipotle in recent weeks.
#ChipotleScare," tweeted Sarah Smith, 25, from Los Angeles.
Chipotle Mexican Grill recently said it's stopping the sales of pork in some markets because a supplier didn't meet company standards.
On top of the E Coli and Salmonella concerns that led to an ongoing outbreak, the fast-casual brand has had its fair share of struggles with supply chain management.
The Mexican-food chain announced that it will start testing vegan meat alternatives in some locations across the United States.
